Award.AwardTitle: LSAMP Bridges to the Baccalaureate: Building Pathways through Connection and Direction for URM Students in STEM

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Valencia College in Orlando, FL on behalf of the Central Florida STEM Alliance (CFSA) is seeking funding under the LSAMP B2B program to double the number of underrepresented minority (URM) STEM students (from 321 to 642) transferring from three community colleges to the University of Central Florida (UCF) and other universities. The target population for this project is African Americans and Hispanic students. The community colleges within the Alliance are: Valencia College, a designated Hispanic Serving Institution, fiscal agent and project lead, (VC), Lake-Sumter State College (LSSC), and Seminole State College of Florida (SSC). This project will expand and focus efforts toward building a system and infrastructure for URM students in STEM majors. This project will focus efforts to increase the transfer rate of underrepresented minorities through focused efforts including: 1) providing clear and targeted advising; 2) providing information about STEM fields and career opportunities; 3) encouraging their projective identity as a STEM professional; and 4) increasing opportunities for students to conduct research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Central Florida STEM Alliance (CFSA), established August 2013, proposed to double the number of underrepresented minority (URM) STEM students transferring from three community colleges in the Central Florida area to the University of Central Florida (UCF). The project’s target population was Black/African American and Hispanic students. CFSA colleges included: Valencia College, a designated Hispanic-serving institution, fiscal agent and project lead; Lake-Sumter State College; and Seminole State College of Florida. This project aimed to reach its goal by: 1) providing clear, targeted advising and information about STEM fields and career opportunities; 2) encouraging students’ identity development as emerging STEM professionals; and 3) increasing opportunities for students to conduct research and gain other STEM professional experiences.     

Intellectual Merit:

CFSA colleges implemented activities that were based on research, higher education literature, tested best practices in other colleges, and local experience with the academic and social factors that enable URM students to complete associate degrees, transfer successfully to university, and earn STEM bachelor degrees. While implementing and assessing various strategies within their contexts, alliance colleges contributed to what is known about:

  • building and maintaining a strong STEM culture in small, rural colleges where such cultures did not exist previously;
  • establishing and sustaining a first-of-its-kind tutoring model at large suburban colleges;
  • implementing, refining, and disseminating a cohort-based model for STEM workplace experiences through undergraduate research; laboratory, industry, and community agency placements; and outreach program facilitation within very large urban/suburban colleges;
  • developing innovative approaches to leverage internal and external resources to enhance progress toward the project’s goal; and
  • expanding system capacity for increased URM participation and completion in STEM through new partnerships and collaborations across institutions, business and industry, local, state, and federal agencies, and non-profit community organizations.

Broader Impacts:

Through well-planned, delivered, and assessed strategies, CFSA colleges successfully increased the number of URM students transferring into bachelor-degree STEM programs at UCF. As diversity in STEM education and careers is a high priority for each college, CFSA institutions are positioned to continue to serve a diverse undergraduate population and to increase participation of URM students who will improve and enhance the quality of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics, as they bring much-needed perspectives to research and innovation.

Significant Results

  • LSAMP Program Enrollment – CFSA partners enrolled more than 2,300 students, with most students identifying as Black/African American and Hispanic. The level of student engagement varied, with large numbers of students participating in a few discrete activities for a few hours to a smaller number of students participating in more intensive, longer-term experiences.
  • Engagement in STEM – Alliance colleges and partners provided a large number and variety of STEM-related learning experiences for students, faculty, and staff. Students (7,584) and faculty/staff (1,510) engaged in 433 project activities designed to support the grant's goal while building stronger, meaningful student-student and student-faculty connections.
  • STEM Major Declarations – Between Fall 2014 and Fall 2016, partners realized a 4.8% increase in the number of URM students declaring STEM majors.
  • Transfers – The number of URM associate degree graduates transferring into baccalaureate STEM majors increased by 19.6% over the baseline (from 321 to 384). This result, while far from the very ambitious project goal, is significant because it both reflects the complexity of this work within a community college context and speaks to the potential of achieving even greater outcomes with a more targeted approach for deeper, longer-term engagement. A 20% gain in four years signals the real possibility of reaching, over a longer timeframe, the goal to double the number of URM students transferring in STEM majors.

Key Accomplishments

  • Dedicated STEM Advising – CFSA established and institutionalized three positions for dedicated advisors to support the associate degree completion and transfer readiness of URM students in STEM majors.
  • Peer Learning Support – Alliance colleges expanded, or implemented for the first time, the supplemental learning (supplemental instruction) model for peer-tutoring. Each institution used the model to support the academic success of students enrolled in gateway courses for STEM majors.
  • STEM Professionalization – Partners collaborated to implement an annual conference. This event permitted many URM students to attend their first STEM conference. Among students completing both pre- and post-surveys for each conference, the overall percentage of first-time attendees at the conferences was 71.9%. Other students attended national conferences, shared their research, and made connections for future internship and research opportunities.
  • Alliance Collaborations and Enhanced System Capacity – The partners’ purposeful collaborations resulted in numerous opportunities for students to expand their communities of STEM peers and networks of STEM professionals through shared co-curricular experiences. Some of these experiences are captured in photos accompanying this report.
  • Undergraduate Research and Assistantships/Internships – Project staff worked with various partners to expand opportunities for students to conduct undergraduate research, complete science laboratory assistantships/internships, and gain other knowledge, skills, and habits of mind critical in STEM careers.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/13/2017
Modified by: Kathleen A Plinske

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The Central Florida STEM Alliance (CFSA), established August 2013, proposed to double the number of underrepresented minority (URM) STEM students transferring from three community colleges in the Central Florida area to the University of Central Florida (UCF). The project?s target population was Black/African American and Hispanic students. CFSA colleges included: Valencia College, a designated Hispanic-serving institution, fiscal agent and project lead; Lake-Sumter State College; and Seminole State College of Florida. This project aimed to reach its goal by: 1) providing clear, targeted advising and information about STEM fields and career opportunities; 2) encouraging students? identity development as emerging STEM professionals; and 3) increasing opportunities for students to conduct research and gain other STEM professional experiences. Intellectual Merit: CFSA colleges implemented activities that were based on research, higher education literature, tested best practices in other colleges, and local experience with the academic and social factors that enable URM students to complete associate degrees, transfer successfully to university, and earn STEM bachelor degrees. While implementing and assessing various strategies within their contexts, alliance colleges contributed to what is known about: building and maintaining a strong STEM culture in small, rural colleges where such cultures did not exist previously; establishing and sustaining a first-of-its-kind tutoring model at large suburban colleges; implementing, refining, and disseminating a cohort-based model for STEM workplace experiences through undergraduate research; laboratory, industry, and community agency placements; and outreach program facilitation within very large urban/suburban colleges; developing innovative approaches to leverage internal and external resources to enhance progress toward the project?s goal; and expanding system capacity for increased URM participation and completion in STEM through new partnerships and collaborations across institutions, business and industry, local, state, and federal agencies, and non-profit community organizations. Broader Impacts: Through well-planned, delivered, and assessed strategies, CFSA colleges successfully increased the number of URM students transferring into bachelor-degree STEM programs at UCF. As diversity in STEM education and careers is a high priority for each college, CFSA institutions are positioned to continue to serve a diverse undergraduate population and to increase participation of URM students who will improve and enhance the quality of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics, as they bring much-needed perspectives to research and innovation. Significant Results LSAMP Program Enrollment – CFSA partners enrolled more than 2,300 students, with most students identifying as Black/African American and Hispanic. The level of student engagement varied, with large numbers of students participating in a few discrete activities for a few hours to a smaller number of students participating in more intensive, longer-term experiences. Engagement in STEM – Alliance colleges and partners provided a large number and variety of STEM-related learning experiences for students, faculty, and staff. Students (7,584) and faculty/staff (1,510) engaged in 433 project activities designed to support the grant's goal while building stronger, meaningful student-student and student-faculty connections. STEM Major Declarations – Between Fall 2014 and Fall 2016, partners realized a 4.8% increase in the number of URM students declaring STEM majors. Transfers – The number of URM associate degree graduates transferring into baccalaureate STEM majors increased by 19.6% over the baseline (from 321 to 384). This result, while far from the very ambitious project goal, is significant because it both reflects the complexity of this work within a community college context and speaks to the potential of achieving even greater outcomes with a more targeted approach for deeper, longer-term engagement. A 20% gain in four years signals the real possibility of reaching, over a longer timeframe, the goal to double the number of URM students transferring in STEM majors. Key Accomplishments Dedicated STEM Advising – CFSA established and institutionalized three positions for dedicated advisors to support the associate degree completion and transfer readiness of URM students in STEM majors. Peer Learning Support – Alliance colleges expanded, or implemented for the first time, the supplemental learning (supplemental instruction) model for peer-tutoring. Each institution used the model to support the academic success of students enrolled in gateway courses for STEM majors. STEM Professionalization – Partners collaborated to implement an annual conference. This event permitted many URM students to attend their first STEM conference. Among students completing both pre- and post-surveys for each conference, the overall percentage of first-time attendees at the conferences was 71.9%. Other students attended national conferences, shared their research, and made connections for future internship and research opportunities. Alliance Collaborations and Enhanced System Capacity – The partners? purposeful collaborations resulted in numerous opportunities for students to expand their communities of STEM peers and networks of STEM professionals through shared co-curricular experiences. Some of these experiences are captured in photos accompanying this report. Undergraduate Research and Assistantships/Internships – Project staff worked with various partners to expand opportunities for students to conduct undergraduate research, complete science laboratory assistantships/internships, and gain other knowledge, skills, and habits of mind critical in STEM careers.
